exchange.text: Diesel's garage is around here somewhere. Nobody knows exactly where.
I heard it moves. Like a ghost shop.
Garages don't move.
Diesel's does.
Old school racers built this scene. Before the money. Before the cameras.
Back when a race was a handshake and a quarter mile. Nothing else.
Simpler times. Better times? Depends who you ask.
This is where the real races happen. No crowds. No bets. Just driving.
Nobody comes here to show off. You come here to test yourself.
And if the car breaks, nobody hears the explosion. Win-win.
Factory shut down six months ago. Now it's just us and the rats. The rats are better company.
Smell that? Diesel fuel and regret. The signature scent of Industrial.
I thought that was just you.
Funny. Your car smells worse.
This warehouse has better tools than most shops. Everything you need, if you know where to look.
And if you don't?
Then you don't belong here.
Straight-line racing through the factory corridor. Two thousand feet, no margin.
What's at the end?
A wall. That's why you brake. Or you don't, and we talk about you in past tense.
Diesel used to race here every night. Twenty years ago, he owned these streets. Now he just watches.
Power plant's still running. Whole block vibrates at night. You can feel it through the steering wheel.
That's not the power plant. That's my subwoofer.
Your subwoofer doesn't shake a city block. Sit down.
No streetlights down this stretch. Pure headlights.
That's how it should be. Your car, your lights, your skill. Nothing else.
There's an engine bay in the back of the old foundry. Guys strip cars there. No questions asked.
Security guard here does a loop every forty-five minutes. That's our window.
You timed the security guard?
Preparation isn't paranoia. It's professionalism.
They tested an engine in there last week. Shook the windows three buildings over.
What kind of engine?
The kind that makes you religious. Because you start praying it doesn't explode.
The concrete here is perfect. Smooth, flat, endless. Factories did one thing right.
Built for forklifts. Inherited by us. Circle of life.
This is hallowed ground. Champions were made on this concrete. Legends too. They're not always the same thing.
Did Diesel really build a car out of spare parts from this factory?
That's what they say. Took factory steel, forged his own headers. The man's a blacksmith with an engine.
Rain turns this whole district into a skating rink.
Oil on concrete plus water. Might as well be ice.
Late night in Industrial. Nothing but factory hum and engine noise. This is my church.
